DataElement.preferredName: Colony Forming Unit Laboratory Procedure Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the colony forming unit laboratory procedure type.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A unit of measurement of viable bacterial numbers. Colony forming unit (CFU) is the minimum number of separable cells, which is able to produce a visible colony of progeny. The examples of CFU usage include but not limited to the measurement of the number of bacteria present in the environment, and the ability of stem cells to produce cells of single or multiple lineages._Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A unit of measurement of viable bacterial numbers. Colony forming unit (CFU) is the minimum number of separable cells, which is able to produce a visible colony of progeny. The examples of CFU usage include but not limited to the measurement of the number of bacteria present in the environment, and the ability of stem cells to produce cells of single or multiple lineages.

Concepts.definition: The minimum number of separable cells which is able to produce a detectable colony of progeny. Examples of CFU usage include, but are not limited to, the measurement of the number of viable bacteria present in the environment, and the ability of stem cells to produce cells of single or multiple lineages.

Property.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A unit of measurement of viable bacterial numbers. Colony forming unit (CFU) is the minimum number of separable cells, which is able to produce a visible colony of progeny. The examples of CFU usage include but not limited to the measurement of the number of bacteria present in the environment, and the ability of stem cells to produce cells of single or multiple lineages._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A leucocyte with conspicuous cytoplasmic granules. In humans the granulocytes are also classified as polymorphonuclear leucocytes and are subdivided according to the staining properties of the granules into eosinophils, basophils and neutrophils. (from On-line Medical Dictionary): Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: A type of white blood cell that surrounds and kills microorganisms, removes dead cells, and stimulates the action of other immune system cells.

Concepts.definition: A type of leukocyte with a multilobed nucleus and cytoplasmic granules. The unique morphology of the nucleus has led to their also being known as polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMLs or PMNs). Granulocytes are subdivided according to the staining properties of their granules into eosinophils (red with acidic dye), basophils (blue with basic dye), and neutrophils (not amenable to staining with either acidic or basic dyes).
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

A cell that arises from stem cells and/or bone marrow-derived monocytes that function in different aspects of host defense and tissue repair; such as phagocytosis, cytotoxic activity, and regulation of the immune response (antigen presentation and T-cell activation).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete.: A group of cells or organisms grown from a single progenitor.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
A group of cells or organisms grown from a single progenitor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.: A unit of viable cell concentration defined as the minimum number of hematopoietic stem cells able to produce a detectable colony of erythroid burst forming cells.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
A unit of viable cell concentration defined as the minimum number of hematopoietic stem cells able to produce a detectable colony of erythroid burst forming cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.: A functional (qualitative) as well as quantitative assay that is utilized as an indicator of granulopoiesis reconstitution.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
A functional (qualitative) as well as quantitative assay that is utilized as an indicator of granulopoiesis reconstitution.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.: A functional (qualitative) as well as quantitative assay that is utilized as an indicator of granulopoiesis reconstitution.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
A functional (qualitative) as well as quantitative assay that is utilized as an indicator of granulopoiesis reconstitution.
